Article Title: Tourists stuck 120ft up in air: Sky dining goes wrong in Kerala; rescue under way - video
Article Text: NEW DELHI: Several tourists were left suspended nearly 120 feet above ground at a private sky-dining facility in Kerala's Anachal, Idukki, after a crane suffered a technical failure on Friday. The visitors remained stuck for over one and a half hours until rescue teams arrived at the site.The incident occurred near Munnar where a crane-operated dining platform, part of an adventure tourism initiative, had been offering visitors an aerial dining experience. The system, introduced only a few months ago, allows up to 16 people to be seated at a time, lifting them high above the valley for about half an hour while they dine with panoramic views.According to local reports the platform could not be lowered due to a mechanical fault believed to be related to the crane‚Äôs fuse. Fire and security personnel deployed from Munnar were working on alternative methods, including lowering individuals using ropes.
Article Summary: Several tourists were left suspended nearly 120 feet above ground at a private sky-dining facility in Kerala's Anachal, Idukki. The visitors remained stuck for over one and a half hours until rescue teams arrived at the site. The incident occurred near Munnar where a crane-operated dining platform had been offering visitors an aerial dining experience.

Chapter 7's map draws inspiration from Hollywood and the West Coast. Accordingly, it is expected to have scenic views, surfing spots, and coastal landscapes. The new island will feature fresh POIs themed around California's iconic locations.

Article Title: Mark Cuban to Perplexity, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Microsoft: You are overspending on AI, only one you will ...
Article Text:

Billionaire investor and Shark Tank judge Mark Cuban has now issued a warning to leading artificial intelligence companies including Perplexity, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Microsoft and Meta. Cuban has argued that all these companies are overspending in the race to build the world‚Äôs most powerful AI model. As reported by Business Insider, speaking in the Pioneers of AI podcast, Cuban compared today‚Äôs AI arms race to the search engine boom of 1990s. The search engine boom ultimately ended with Google dominating the market and leaving all the rivals behind.‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got five, six, whatever it is, companies that are trying to create the ultimate foundational model that we all depend on,‚Äù Cuban said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost like in the ‚Äô90s when all the search engines were competing pre-Google‚Ä¶ Now, we know with search engines it‚Äôs Google, and then there‚Äôs Bing, as, like, 1 or 2% and DuckDuckGo has got a half a percent. So it‚Äôs effectively a winner-take-all.‚ÄùLike many other world leaders and analysts, Cuban has also cautioned that the massive investments done on AI could ultimately lead to the creation of a bubble. ‚ÄúThey may be overspending,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúAnd if they overspend or get too caught up, the bubble is in the competition between all those models because that could pop just like that with any new technology.‚ÄùAlong with this, he also raised concerns about the infrastructure costs behind AI, majorly the massive and expensive data centers which are being built to power large models. ‚ÄúI just can‚Äôt imagine over a 10-year period that we aren‚Äôt going to improve the technology enough that if you overspend on today‚Äôs technology, it just doesn‚Äôt feel right to me,‚Äù Cuban added.Cuban also emphasised that the disruption AI will not come from incremental improvements but from something ‚Äúincredible‚Äù that no one sees coming. ‚ÄúSomebody‚Äôs going to come up with some incredible shit, right? If I knew what it was, I‚Äôd do it,‚Äù he said, suggesting that the current race may be blindsided by a breakthrough outside the existing competition.Cuban said he recognizes the same mix of hype, excitement, and overspending now playing out in AI. ‚ÄúThey anticipate for at least another decade spending every penny they have,‚Äù he said of the major model developers. ‚ÄúI mean, if that‚Äôs not ripe for disruption to come up with better ways, I don‚Äôt know what is.‚Äù

Article Title: Two reasons Apple is likely going back to Intel, five years after break-up

Five years after Apple famously broke up with Intel to design its own revolutionary M-series chips, the tech giant may be rekindling the relationship‚Äîbut this time, with a twist. Supply chain analyst Ming-Chi Kuo reports Intel could start manufacturing Apple's M-series processors by 2027, though Apple would retain full control over chip design while Intel handles production.The chipmaker could begin producing Apple's lowest-end M-series processors using its 18AP advanced manufacturing process as early as the second or third quarter of 2027, Kuo revealed in a post on X (formerly Twitter). The Intel-made Apple Silicon would likely power the upcoming MacBook Air, iPad Air, and iPad Pro models, with expected production volumes between 15-20 million units.Unlike the previous relationship where Intel designed x86-based processors for Macs, this partnership would see Intel solely manufacturing Apple-designed ARM-based chips. Taiwan-based TSMC would continue supplying the majority of Apple's chips, including higher-end variants and iPhone processors.The deal could help Apple demonstrate its commitment to buying American by incorporating more US-based companies into its supply chain, Kuo theorised. Bloomberg reported in September that Intel approached Apple about securing an investment as part of its turnaround efforts, with Apple CEO Tim Cook previously telling CNBC the company would "love to see Intel come back".The US government acquired approximately 10% of Intel in an August deal brokered by the Trump administration, positioning the chipmaker as critical to domestic semiconductor production.While TSMC remains Apple's primary chip supplier, diversifying manufacturing sources addresses supply chain management requirements, according to Kuo. This strategic move would provide Apple with a backup option for its entry-level processors.Apple has already signed a non-disclosure agreement with Intel and obtained preliminary design specifications, with key development milestones tracking as expected. The company awaits Intel's updated design kit scheduled for the first quarter of 2026.For Intel, landing Apple as a foundry client would validate its turnaround efforts and potentially attract other premium customers. For Apple, it's calculated risk management wrapped in political optics‚Äîkeeping options open while maintaining technological leadership.

Article Title: Ekman, who linked facial expressions to emotions, dies at 91
Article Text: Paul Ekman, a psychologist who linked thousands of facial expressions to the emotions they often subconsciously conveyed, and who used his research to advise FBI interrogators and screeners for the Transportation Security Administration as well as Hollywood animators, died Nov 17 at his home in San Francisco. He was 91.Ekman sought to add scientific exactitude to the human impulse to interpret how others feel through their facial expressions. He recorded 18 types of smiles, for example, distinguishing between a forced smile and a spontaneous one; a genuine smile, he discovered, crinkles the orbicularis oculi muscle - that is, it creates crow's feet around the eyes.Sometimes described as the world's most famous face reader, Ekman was influential in reshaping the way facial expressions were understood - as the product of evolution rather than environment - and his findings crossed over to popular culture.As a young researcher in the late 1960s, Ekman changed the scientific consensus on facial expressions. In the postwar era, the conventional wisdom of eminent anthropologists like Margaret Mead was that human facial expressions were learned and that they varied across cultures. Ekman believed otherwise. He showed photographs of people making faces expressing 30 different emotions - including anger, joy and fear - to subjects in the United States, Japan and South America.Across cultures, the study's participants linked the expressions they were shown with the same emotions.He then travelled to Papua New Guinea with a colleague, Wallace V Friesen, and showed the same pictures to some 300 Indigenous people who had no exposure to modern media and could not have learned to interpret faces that way. These subjects also connected the expressions to the same emotions."There is a pan-cultural element in facial expressions of emotion," Ekman wrote in a paper in 1970 on returning to the United States.
Article Summary: Paul Ekman, a psychologist who linked thousands of facial expressions to the emotions they often subconsciously conveyed, died Nov 17 at his home in San Francisco. Ekman was influential in reshaping the way facial expressions were understood. He recorded 18 types of smiles, for example, distinguishing between a forced smile and a spontaneous one.

Article Title: Nominee vs legal heir: What is the difference and who has claim on assets? All you need to know

Who is a Nominee?

Difference between a Nominee and a Legal heir

Aspect Nominee Legal Heir Role Custodian Owner Transfer of Assets Can be done without any legal formalities. Requires testamentary documents for proof of ownership. Powers No power to transact, use, or transfer assets. Power to use and transact assets as an owner. Appointment Owner can appoint anyone, but some institutions specify certain conditions. Determined by succession/personal laws. Legal Right Cannot contest ownership legally. Can contest ownership in a court of law.

When individuals open bank accounts, invest in mutual funds, or buy insurance, they are often asked to name a nominee.However, many people mistakenly assume that the nominee automatically inherits the assets. In reality, the nominee is not always the final recipient ‚Äî the ownership rights belong to the legal heir, reported ET.Understanding the distinction between these two is essential to ensure that your wealth is passed on to the intended beneficiaries.A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets.The nominee‚Äôs role is limited to holding and managing the assets until they are legally transferred to the rightful heirs.According to ET, the nominee cannot sell, trade, or make any transactional decisions about the assets.The account or policy owner can appoint anyone ‚Äî family, friends, or acquaintances ‚Äî as a nominee, though financial institutions often prefer close family members.In some cases, the nominee and the legal heir can be the same person, which helps in ensuring a smoother transfer of assets.The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away.To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will or other testamentary proof.If there is no will ‚Äî a situation known as dying intestate ‚Äî the heir is determined as per the country‚Äôs succession or personal laws, reported ET.While a nominee can initially access the assets, only the legal heir can claim them permanently or challenge ownership in court.Experts quoted by ET emphasise that having clarity on this difference helps avoid disputes and ensures that the savings reach the intended family members or beneficiaries.Therefore, it is advisable to regularly update both nominees and wills to align with one‚Äôs estate planning goals.
Article Summary: A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets. The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away. To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will.

However, with the government‚Äôs focus on digitisation and technological advancement, this process has become much simpler, faster, and more convenient. Pensioners can now submit their certificates digitally from the comfort of their homes using Jeevan Pramaan, a secure, user-friendly, and Aadhaar-based platform.A Life Certificate is an official document that confirms a pensioner is alive. Without it, pension payments are automatically paused by the pension disbursing agency. This verification is essential for preventing fraudulent claims and ensuring that pensions reach the rightful beneficiaries.The Digital Life Certificate (DLC), also known as Jeevan Pramaan, is an advanced biometric-enabled version of the traditional paper certificate.Introduced by the Government of India, it uses Aadhaar-based biometric authentication using either fingerprint or iris scan to verify a pensioner‚Äôs identity. Once verified, a digital certificate is automatically generated and shared with authorised pension disbursing agencies.This online process eliminates the need for physical verification, providing elderly pensioners with a simpler and more accessible way to maintain their pension benefits.According to PIB, The submission of the Life Certificate is mandatory for all pensioners who wish to continue receiving their pension without interruption. This extended window gives senior citizens more time and flexibility to complete the procedure without facing last-minute difficulties.The Jeevan Pramaan process involves two main steps: registering the biometric device and generating the digital certificate.Before using the service, pensioners or operators must register their biometric device such as a fingerprint or iris scanner. Gold, silver hallmarking : Gold and silver jewllery have long been treasured for their beauty and value. However, ensuring their purity and authenticity is important, especially in a market prone to fraudulent practices. This is where the hallmarking scheme comes into play. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about hallmarking charges and its procedures:Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver.It serves as a guarantee of their purity or fineness. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820, according to an ET report.Hallmarking charges are applied per article, regardless of its weight. For gold articles, the charge is Rs 45 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 200 for a consignment. Similarly, for silver articles, the charge is Rs 35 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 150 for a consignment. It's important to note that additional taxes and levies may apply.A consignment refers to a collection of articles with the same fineness, from which a sample is drawn and assayed for compliance. Different lots may exist within a consignment.Anyone can have their hallmarked jewellery tested for purity at an A&H centre by paying a testing fee of Rs. 200 (for testing using the fire assay method as per IS 1418). These centres must be recognized by the BIS. The list of recognized A&H centres is available on the BIS website under the hallmarking section.The primary objective of hallmarking is to safeguard consumers from counterfeit products. To achieve this, the Indian government made hallmarking mandatory for gold jewellery from June 16, 2021. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification ( HUID ) number.If you bought gold jewellery on or before June 30, 2021, it may have old hallmarking signs. These signs include the purity/fineness mark and the BIS emblem, along with two additional indications: the jeweller's identification number and the assay centre's mark/number.However, starting July 1, 2021, these two indications were replaced with a unique alphanumeric HUID code. The hallmark remains valid for the lifetime of the jewellery, and consumers can sell old jewellery, whether hallmarked or un-hallmarked, to jewellers.The HUID, or hallmark Unique Identification number, is a key component of hallmarking in gold jewellery. It's a unique six-digit alphanumeric code assigned to each hallmarked item, allowing for traceability. Customers can verify the HUID number using the 'Verify HUID' feature in the BIS Care App.Since the introduction of the HUID on July 1, 2021, the hallmark on gold jewellery consists of three marks: the BIS logo, the purity of the article in caratage and fineness, and a unique six-digit alphanumeric HUID number.
Article Summary: Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification number.
